item.description:
A high-risk, underground movement has started a new economy free from corruption and manipulation. This new world uses cryptocurrency, a financial system based on secure, anonymous exchange and decentralization. This is where you are at the center of your money – mining, trading, and storing digital coins. But where there is hope, there is hacking. How will you protect your fortune on the blockchain?

BLOCKCHAIN is a 2-4 player strategic action-based card game featuring some of the most captivating aspects of cryptocurrency. You’ll mine for opportunities, trade coins based on changing exchange values, and store coins based on your powerful Block cards. The goal is to collect 10 of each type of coin (Bitcoin, Litecoin, Ethereum, Dash, and Peercoin) in cold storage, but the challenge requires some mischievous maneuvers. Learn how to hack or be hacked during every player’s turn, disrupting the entire game strategy. Demonstrate how your clever planning, good timing, and modish moxie will fill your Vault first!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Brace for Impact! The raging war between the Antillians and the Morkolytes has reached its highest peak. In a final ferocious siege, the rival aliens battle for control of the star system. Each species gathers their forces, planet by planet, as tensions grow. In the end, command of the star system can fall under only one dominion, but whose?

Stellar Siege is a 2-player tactical card game in which you play as one of the rival alien species. You will deploy aliens from your hand into your siege forces at each planet. Hand management is the key to victory, because the number of cards in your hand dictates to which planet you will deploy your alien that turn. Outnumbering your opponent at a planet means you conquer it. At the end of the game, the player who has conquered the most planets wins!

—description from the publisher

Ingression is a 2 player strategy game in two phases and has a fluid maze that changes each turn through player actions. In the first phase, the Build Phase, players work to build a maze of cards in a 5 x 5 grid.

After the maze is built, the Ingression Phase begins. Players navigate the maze by creating new paths on the grid. At the beginning of a turn, a play may draw a new tile and replace a tile already on the board, or turn a tile to create a new path. One of these actions must be taken each turn, and the player also must move if possible.

To win, a player must move their pawn to the other side before their opponent reaches theirs.

The game consists of 39 maze tiles and 2 home tiles, two movement cubes (blank red and blue colored dice), and a small full color instruction manual. It is designed to be small, portable, and easy to learn. Ingression can be taught to new players in as little as 5 minutes. The game does not require much space to play, somewhere between 1 and 2 square feet depending on how the players lay it out.

—description from the publisher

Atlantis sunk, Alexandria burnt, Athens razed

The Eschaton happened and the ancient world is broken. Chaos reigns where order was maintained for generations. The Olympian gods are dead, their laws forgotten. The lands belong to the monstrous Primordials.

A giant iron ship cuts through the turbulent seas, besieged from all sides by enemies who would see its mission fail. But the Argo’s course stays ever true! For it carries the only thing that can oppose the Primordials: Titans, weaponized for war.

Resist the Truth of the Labyrinth. Confront the Nietzschean and end his Abysswatch. Defy the inevitable fates woven by the mad Delphian Oracles.

Mend the world!

What awaits you

Take control of the giant ship’s crew, the valiant Argonauts, train them and send on adventures into the dangerous and mysterious lands of Ancient World (and beyond...). Learn the secrets of the Golden People and create new technologies that will give you the edge in combat - and outside of it. Manage your resources and develop your base of operations. Gather allies and forge political alliances with the world’s factions. And, most important of all, tame the Titans, arm them, evolve them and ride them to battle with the kaiju-like Primordials. All in this fully co-operative board game experience for 1-4 players.

Tactical Combat. Narrative-driven gameplay. Strategic campaign.

In Cartel, you are a head of one of the biggest drug cartels that want to enrich themselves in the quickest and easiest possible way, that why you will plot against other cartels and try to steal their money or simply destroy it while trying to laundry your own cash. Sometimes you will invest your money in some buildings that will generate you some goods or produce you clean money. Player who will get the most clean cash at the end of the game will be named the greatest drug lord in the world.

Cartel is a small game for 2-4 players with multi use cards in which you will be fighting other players while building your own drug empire. During the game players will be facing different phases in which they will be bribing some contacts to enter restricted areas, using multi use action cards in few possible ways like: using it for its action, taking them as the goods or connecting them to own empire as buildings that will help us during the game.

There are few interesting mechanics in the game like area control; card management; small engine-building that works very well and with the smart design of multi use cards each and every game is an unique experience.

So do you have what it takes to take the whole drug cartel and show everyone who is the fierce force to be reckoned with?

—description from the publisher

name.value: Here I Stand (500th Anniversary Reprint Edition)
Here I Stand: Riforma e Controriforma, 1517-1555

item.description:
Here I Stand: Wars of the Reformation 1517-1555 is the first game in over 25 years to cover the political and religious conflicts of early 16th Century Europe. Few realize that the greatest feats of Martin Luther, Jean Calvin, Ignatius Loyola, Henry VIII, Charles V, Francis I, Suleiman the Magnificent, Ferdinand Magellan, Hernando Cortes, and Nicolaus Copernicus all fall within this narrow 40-year period of history. This game covers all the action of the period using a unique card-driven game system that models both the political and religious conflicts of the period on a single point-to-point map.

There are six main powers in the game, each with a unique path to victory.

Here I Stand was due for a reprint in 2017, but with October 31, 2017 being the 500th anniversary of Martin Luther's posting of his 95 Theses, Ed Beach and his team of Here I Stand enthusiasts have put together a series of enhancements to the original game that transform this reprint into a deluxe 500th anniversary treatment.

500th Anniversary Edition Enhancements include:

 6 brand new cards added to the deck, including Thomas More, Thomas Cromwell, Rough Wooing, and Imperial Coronation.
 Revisions to over 15 existing cards including Copernicus, Master of Italy, and Machiavelli to allow for more exciting in-game play and additional possibilities for diplomatic deals.
 A new Chateau construction table is now used to resolve France's Patron of the Arts home card plays.
 Several Virgin Queen rule updates are incorporated back into Here I Stand, affecting minor power activation, piracy, spice trading, and foreign wars.




Game Components:

 Four and a half full-color counter sheets
 116 Strategy Cards
 One 22"x34" Mounted Mapsheet
 Player Aid Cards (11"x17" & 8.5"x11")
 Rules/Scenario Book
 One ten-sided die




DESIGNER: Ed Beach
MAP & CARD ART: Mark Simonitch
COUNTER ART: Mark Simonitch and Rodger B. MacGowan

—description from the publisher

name.value: Il Gioco di Cotto e Mangiato

item.description:
You are part of the staff who must prepare the recipes for the next episodes of Cotto and Mangiato. When you notice that some essential ingredients for making dishes are not available, you go to the nearby market to try to recover the missing ingredients as quickly as possible, taking them from the available stock of ingredients, as an action.

The game plan represents a market, with 11 stalls, each of which has several products. Each stall is identified by a symbol that determines the type of products on sale.

The player who will be able to complete the higher number of recipes will win the game.

A fun game for the whole family full of unusual anecdotes. Are you ready to play? An exciting challenge awaits you!

The game proceed with a series of questions and challenges on the general culture, sports, arts, comics, movie etc.

The player that will answer the most correct questions will win the game.

A fun game for the whole family full of unusual anecdotes. Are you ready to play? An exciting challenge awaits you!

The game proceed with a series of questions and challenges on the general culture, sports, arts, comics, movie etc.

The player that will answer the most correct questions will win the game.

The Dragon Warrior of ancient China needs your help! You must travel with Po and take on the great responsibility of training a village of clumsy Pandas to help him defeat the evil Kai... are your kung fu skills sharp enough to fight with Po to victory?

Travel around the Valley of Peace, buy Po's journey cards, build Jade Palaces, complete Fortune cookie Mysteries and try to get your hands on as many Chopsticks as possible from Mr Ping's Noodle Box!

Belly Gong into this awesome kung fu adventure and give your opponents a heaping dose of justice in this Kung Fu Panda 3 Monopoly Junior! Time for some Skadooshing!

—description from the publisher

The king was accidentally turned into a frog! Gather your friends, stride across the forest, and find the correct ingredients to prepare a potion that will cure him.

Magic Maze Kids is a cooperative game that makes the original mechanisms of Magic Maze accessible to young players. Everyone controls all of the heroes, but only in one direction! Tutorials gradually teach you the rules, and several levels make the game evolve with the children.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Keys to the Castle is a tile-based game of strategy and luck. Players must open and close doors (the tiles) to move along a path and be the first to cross to the other side.

Special cards are played to hacksaw through barred doors, use a skeleton key to unlock padlocked doors, throw a net on a player to stop them in their tracks or use secret passageways to maneuver your way to the other side.

The game is easy to learn and quick to play. With the tiles acting as the "board", there is a new outcome to each game every time the tiles and cards are shuffled.

A board game which shares the history of a pharmacy in Estonia which pre-dates Columbus' arrival in the Americas. Players take turns rolling a die and moving their pawn, stopping on various spaces to learn more about the history of the pharmacy. Some spots will race you ahead, some will set you back. The first player to land exactly on the finish spot is the winner.

The pilots start at the red or blue circled spaces in the middle, the planes on the circled spaces (1st and 3rd line) on the left and right side of the game board. The goal of the game is to occupy the enemy airport with the pilot in the middle, surrounded by the planes. Movement is determined by the number die in any direction. If the color die shows the color of the active player, he gets another turn (up to 3 turns in a row). On the roll of a 6 a plane or the pilot has to be moved from ist starting position, if possible. If a figure lands on a space with an enemy figure, the enemy is sent back to a starting space, now including the 2nd line. The figures can't move into their own airport.

name.value: Warhammer 40,000 Dice Masters: Battle for Ultramar Campaign Box

item.description:
Set in the dark sci-fantasy world of Warhammer 40,000, Warhammer 40,000 Dice Masters allows players to build teams of iconic characters and warriors to battle it out for supremacy using custom dice and cards. Warhammer 40,000 Dice Masters uses the game system designed by Mike Elliott and Eric M. Lang for Dice Masters and is completely compatible with other games in the line. Four factions are available when the series first launches, and players can either build teams using a single faction or mix and match to create their own Dice Masters team.

The initial release of Warhammer 40,000 Dice Masters will be centered around the Battle for Ultramar Campaign Box. This starter box has fixed content set that includes everything needed for two players to play the game: a force of Ultramarines, a force of Deathguard, Sidekick dice, Basic Action dice, and dice bags for both players. More than twelve characters appear in the set, including the Ultramarines Primarch Roboute Guilliman and Chief Librarian Tigurius, as well as the Deathguard heroes Typhus and Mortarion.

item.description:
MADE IN USA!

78 Cards: Poker size 2.5"X 3.5"

300gsm Linen

Custom Tuck Box

Shrink Wrapped box and cards inside.

If you have ever played the game "PIT," and you have ANY interest whatsoever in cryptocurrency, you will LOVE this game! It is an adaptation of the well known game "Pit," but instead of commodities like wheat, soybeans, corn... it uses the HOTTEST cryptos on the market! Each card has must know facts about the coin itself and the game comes loaded with must know facts before investing. Cryptocurrency is the biggest game changer since the invention of the internet, YET fewer than 1 in 4000 people even own a bitcoin! Whether you are a serious investor or just want to have a fun time, this is the game for you! Get ahead of the curve and have a blast! Become familiar with crypto while playing the funnest game in your closet!

Bitcoin the Card Game is fun for ages 7+ and for 3-8 Players. Multiple decks can be used for larger groups! 78 cards per deck; 8 suits (coins) of 9 identical cards, a hacker card, a miner card, an instruction card, 2 must know bitcoin facts cards, and a future of bitcoin card. Only the coins and the hacker and miner cards are used in game play.

OBJECT:

Be the first crypto trader to score a total of 5000 points. As soon as the dealer yells, "BITCOIN," you become a crypto coin trader trying to "own the marker" of one of the following 8 coins: Bitcoin, Ethereal, Litecoin, Monero, Bitcoin Cash, NEM, Dash, or Coinye West. You "own" that particular coin when you have in your hand all 9 cards of the same coin.

SET UP

1. Select a dealer

2. Prepare a score sheet

3. Use one complete 9 card suit per each player in the game plus the hacker and miner cards. Leave all other cards out of the game.

4. The dealer shuffles the deck and deals out all the cards in play face down. Each player should have 9 and the players with the miner and hacker cards should have 10.

5. Pick up the cards and arrange them by suit. Don't let anyone else see them. Decide which coin you want to own. Hint: pick the coin you have the most of in your hand.

6. When everyone has sorted their cards the dealer says, "Bitcoin" and the trading begins.

PLAY

As soon as the dealer said, "bitcoin!" everyone starts trading. To trade, select 1-4 cards from your hand of the same suit that you do not want to own and say, "one! one!" or "two! two!" depending on how many cards you want to trade. You may trade with any opponent who is calling out the same number. Sometimes a particular opponent will want to trade fewer cards than you do. In this case you can lower your bid and trade the smaller number. you CANNOT look at the cards you are trading for until the trade is complete, NOT can you reveal which cards you are trading. It is a race to see who can collect all 9 the quickest. The first player to call out the coin they have once they own the coin wins the number of points associated with that particular coin. No one else wins any points that round.

WILD CARDS

If someone goes out and you hold the miner and/or hacker cards you lose 200 points per wild card in your hand. If you have 8 cards of a singer coin and the miner card, you may lay down all 9 (8 coins plus the miner card) and shout out "DOUBLE BITCOIN, DOUBLE MONERO! etc..) In his case you win double the points on the card. If you have the hacker card in your hand you may not lay down your cards until you have gotten rid of it. You jay trade both cards together or separately or with another coin but you CANNOT trade more than 4 cards at a time.

COINYE WEST

This coin is worth much less than the other coins but if someone collects all 9 everyone else loses points. Double Coinye means everyone also loses double as well!

WINNING

The game is played several times until a player has a total of 5000 points.

name.value: ウサギのロストレガシー：聖杯探索 (Usagi no Lost Legacy: Holy Grail)

item.description:
In the face of political instability and financial turmoil of the American Revolution, only one individual came out on top.
ALEXANDER HAMILTON.
Pit your survival instincts and spending savvy against all the Founding Fathers (and Mothers) in this historical action card game whose simple objective is as old as Ameritocracy itself:
get all the money or die trying.

—description from the back of the box

This is a solitaire adventure playable with ordinary playing cards.

Four intrepid heroes are on a cross-country trip with the goal of getting the heir to the kingdom safely across the border. On the way they have to fight enemy soldiers, but this takes a toll on their strength. As they accumulate money, they may be able to hire sympathizers to fight their battles for them, but when they are alone or out of money, they have to fight their way through on their own.

Clubs represent hostile forces, Spades represent the heroes and their sympathizers, Hearts represent hit points, and Diamonds represent money. One card at a time is turned over and placed on the layout in its appropriate place. Every time a Club is turned up, the player has to deal with it using the resources available. The goal is to escape all the hostile forces and get to the border safely without being captured.

The Life You Can Lead is an effective altruism game with a reincarnation theme and interesting trivia questions and funny action cards. The players start out as humans with incomes randomly chosen from the real-world distribution, although less fortunate players may also reincarnate as chickens and dung beetles. The players collaboratively try to achieve normative good (donating to charities and answering trivia so as to get 1000 human QALYs (quality-adjusted life-years), 10,000 animal QALYs, and 10 x-risk points (x-risk points help prevent human extinction.)) Additionally, players have private moralities that give them alternative ways to win the game, such as moral relativist, sadist, preference utilitarian, nihilist etc.

—description from the designer

Lightyears from earth there is a small planet called Caturn-1. In many ways it is very similar to Earth of about 1000 years ago. There are castles, roads, trees and farms but unlike Earth there are no humans! Felines control the planet. Felines from the four great kingdoms, Forest, Fire, Sea, and Sky. For hundreds of years these four great kingdoms have battled for control of Caturn-1. Until Wildwood proposed a battle to end all battles. Each kingdom will send a FELINE FIGHTING FORCE of eight members to battle for control of the realm and the winning kingdom will rule Caturn-1 forever!

Each player starts with 8 cats, 2 traps, and 2 food laid out face down in front of them. Players take turns attacking opponents by revealing one card from an opponents field and resolving using numbered battled cards.

Dragon Watcher: The Card Game is a strategy and collection card game. Two or more players race to collect dragons while using special abilities to hinder their opponents. Are you ready to become the ultimate Dragon Watcher?

The base game includes enough cards for 2-5 players. If you wish to play a larger, longer game, you can play with two sets shuffled together.

link.value: Dragon Watcher: The Baby Dragons Expansion
Dragon Watcher: The Card Game – Ancient Artifacts

item.description:
The low land is a rough area where hard-working folk make a living by the sweat of their brow. Under constant threat of storm and flood, communities here rally together to build dikes that keep the rising water at bay. But every citizen constructing a dike is one fewer citizen tending flocks and maintaining the family farm. The residents here are constantly torn between selflessness and self-interest, and only those who can strike this delicate balance can thrive in this harsh landscape.

In Lowlands, you carve your farm out of this unforgiving land, gathering and spending resource cards to transform your farmyard into pastures that allow you to profit from breeding sheep. Adding expansions to your farm will unlock new options and score you victory points, but helping to build the dike that collectively protects all players is also rewarded. No matter what, the tide will rise and, if the dike isn't high enough, it could rush in and sweep away your hard-earned profits. Will you sacrifice your own farm for the good of the community, or will you pursue your own agenda? The choice is yours.

Even without the poor weather, life on a farm is one of constant work where you find yourself tending flocks of sheep, extending their pastures, and looking for the right moment to sell them for a profit. To complete all these tasks, Lowlands gives you a group of farmers that you can assign to various tasks around your farm. To get the most out of them, you must think strategically, deciding which actions you want to take and the best time to take them. Once they've been assigned, your farmers help you build a bustling farm where there was once scrubby bushes, trees, and lakes. You begin the game with only two sheep and a small pasture, but your farmyard is rife with possibilities, its many empty spaces inviting you to customize your farm as you see fit.

While you could simply focus on creating more area for your sheep to roam, the game also provides plenty of options for customizing your farm with various buildings and features. Not only are these tiles worth victory points at the end of the game, they also make your farm more efficient and more profitable. You might add a feeding trough to your farm, for example, to immediately earn another sheep and the ability to house two sheep per pasture space instead of just one. Or you could construct a lake cabin on your property to get away from it all for a bit. While this tile doesn't give you any special abilities, it increases the value in victory points of the farmyard spaces immediately adjacent to it. Ultimately, you are free to pursue whatever strategy you see fit, building a farm wholly your own.

On top of the challenges of building a successful farm, of course, you also have to deal with the tempestuous weather that comes with living on the wave-battered coast of the North Sea. Here, the tides always seem to rise a little higher, threatening to take a dent out of your profits by sweeping away some of your flock. To ensure that this doesn't happen, you always have the opportunity to send your farmers to contribute to the dike instead of working on your farm. When you do, you also commit resources to creating dike elements that are added to the board as a buffer against the rising waters. Add enough of these pieces and you might prevent disaster for everyone. The tide turns repeatedly, bringing with it new flood pieces. If there are enough dike elements in place to hold back the rising waters, players' farms are spared. If the dike breaks, however, you could be forced to take dike breach tokens that have adverse effects at the end of the game.

While lending a hand with the dike at the expense of your own farm is certainly a nice gesture that keeps everyone safe from the floodwaters, it has rewards of its own. For each resource you contribute to the dike, you advance one step up the dike track. Not only does advancing far enough on this track grant victory points, it also amplifies your reward if the dike holds and lessens the blow when it breaks. It is in your best interest, then, to keep pace with other players on the dike in order to protect your investments back home one the farm.

—description from the publisher

link.value: テンデイズゲームズ (Ten Days Games)

name.value: Kings of War: The Battle of the Glades Two Player Battle Set

item.description:
The Abyss was spreading; an affront to nature and reality. The Green Lady, in her divine wisdom, had called on the Druid folk to spread the word, forge alliances with the mortal races of the world and stand against the coming dark. The fate of the world is about to be decided in the largest conflict for an age. Whatever the cost, the sickening spread of the Abyss must be stopped!

This set contains everything two players need to get started in Kings of War, including:

Kings of War Gamer's Edition Rulebook, including full rules, 11 complete Army Lists, and more!
Battle of the Glades Guide, including lore, two starter force lists and a mini-campaign!
20 Hard Plastic Lower Abyssals/Flamebearers with Command
20 Hard Plastic Succubi with Command
20 Hard Plastic Naiad Ensnarers/Heartpiercers with Command
20 Hard Plastic Salamanders with Shield or Great Weapons and Command
1 Metal Abyssal Champion with Alternate Components
1 Metal Druid with Alternate Components
Plastic Square Bases
Mantic Points

Dice Wars is a 2-4 player tactics battleground with infinite replay value. Roll armies, shuffle the map, add new rules, play forever.

In this fantasy tactics game of war, players expertly maneuver randomly-generated armies of giant polyhedral dice across an ever-changing hex-grid battlefield to outwit, outplay, and outlast their opponents. Roll your units, discover synergies on the fly, then deploy merciless combos to command your forces to victory!

With hundreds of team compositions, hundreds of map layouts, a rotating set of bonus-granting cities to conquer, and seven optional gameplay challenges (including powerful magic relics, faction bonuses, and prestige units) to customize your gameplay experience, you'll never play the same game twice.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
A light-hearted game of pigs, politics and pandemonium.

This is a card game where you’re creating as much chaos as possible, battling your friends and trying your best to avoid any signs of tranquility… all with the hopes of blazing a path to personal glory. There are two fun and strategically very different “ways” of playing President Bigly and playing is simple… BUT only one pig can be left at the end!

This game is appropriate for all ages, political persuasions and pig lovers alike.

—description from the publisher

link.value: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games

item.description:
BabyIQ is the ultimate game to learn facts about pregnancy and babies. It comes with 400 multiple-choice questions. Correct answers are counted as IQ points. It is played in teams over two rounds. The first round tests your knowledge. The second round tests your memory, making the game accessible and fun. You can take risks to score more points, but will you trust your teammates?

—description from the publisher

SportIQ is the ultimate game for sports lovers. It comes with 400 multiple-choice questions. Correct answers are counted as IQ points. It is played in teams over two rounds. The first round tests your knowledge. The second round tests your memory, making the game accessible and fun. You can take risks to score more points, but will you trust your teammates?

—description from the publisher

Grand Tour USA is the game for travel lovers. Players answer questions using their cards representing states, but no need to be a know-it-all to win. The two types of questions, speed and knowledge, make the game fun and accessible. Correct answers let players advance from state to state and pass the other players to win playing pieces and victory points. The player with the most points at the end wins the game. In this travel-enticing game, discover the states and customs of the United States.

Your challenge in King is to place cubes planks and cylinders on top of each other, without making the whole construction go down. Each turn, you can also choose to move one piece from one tower to the other. Whoever places the crown on the highest level possible wins the game.

King is a game of skills and light strategy.

—description from the publisher

Reclaim Earth - ReArmed is a medium weight mission based combat game utilizing aged military technology in a future post apocalyptic setting.

Players will use scout vehicles to explore the board and discover military components that will allow the building of warplanes, warships and tanks from the WWII era.

Players will deploy their rediscovered military force to battle opponent unit and structure targets on a large 38 zone game board. Playtime ranges from 60 to 90 minutes.

Reclaim Earth - ReArmed will be the first of a series of games under the Reclaim Earth family and setting.

—description from the publisher

Ladrillazo is a historical board game that takes you to the real estate bubble which took place in Spain on the first decade of the XXI Century. These were days of wine and roses: interpretation centers in every town, an airport in every city, 40-year mortgages, construction workers earning salaries like if they were Ministers, Olympic dreams, high-speed trains and golf resorts.

You'll play as the middleman, the one that tricks politicians and building companies into winning the citizen's favor and make some good profit out of some piece of land no one cares about.

Step by step, by speculating, you'll finally reach the upper echelons, will carry on monumental projects and your profit will grow more and more... Until the taxpayer's money runs out; then, the one who has been able to hide and park the bigger amount of their money in offshore tax havens, wins the game.

Ladrillazo includes more than 150 cards with real people and projects carefully documented which depict faithfully Spain during this time.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Ladrillazo es un juego histórico que te traslada a la burbuja inmobiliaria de la primera década del siglo XXI. Fueron días de vino y rosas, un centro de interpretación en cada pueblo, un aeropuerto en cada ciudad, hipotecas a 40 años, albañiles con sueldos de ministro, sueños olímpicos, AVEs y resorts con golf.

Tú serás el intermediario, el conseguidor, el que convence a un par de alcaldes y constructores locales para ganarse el favor del votante y sacar partido a unos terrenillos olvidados.

Poco a poco, especulando e hipotecando, llegarás a las más altas esferas políticas y empresariales, sacarás adelante proyectos faraónicos y tus beneficios serán cada vez mayores... hasta que se agote el dinero del país y gane la partida quien más haya conseguido esconder.

Ladrillazo incluye más de 150 personajes, lugares y proyectos reales cuidadosamente documentados que retratan fielmente la España de la época para contagiarte la fiebre del ladrillo.

—description from the publisher (Spanish)

Would you know who said they'd meekly find another chair when they arrived at the office if they found a stranger sitting in theirs? Or who said they'd put headphones on and pretend to be asleep if the person next to them began chatting on a long flight? All will be revealed as you sit around drinking milky tea, awkwardly discussing your inner Britishness by playing Very British Problems!

—description from the publisher

You start on the starting line. One person reads the question on the card. All players are armed with a wipe clean board and a pad. You write your answer on the pad, they all get read out and you have to guess who said what. However many you get right is how many spaces you move. This is a straight forward party style game where moves race around a track by guessing who said what.

—user summary

This is special anniversary version of Monopoly with a Papa John's Pizza theme. Properties include locations like "Asiago Alley" and the traditional Chance Cards are replaced with "Better Pizza" cards. The play money features a photograph of the owner.

The contents are similar to Monopoly with houses, tokens, dice, etc.

X-O is played on a board showing 129 yellow/orange/red squares where numbers between 1 and 25 can be read.

Each player rolls 3 dice to obtain a number or numbers similar to the one(s) on the square where the player wishes to place one or several of his tokens. For example, a player rolls 3/4/6 : a) he may place 3 tokens on squares "3", "4" and "6" ; b) he may place 2 tokens on square "12" (=3x4) and "6" ; c) he may place 1 token on square "18" (=3x4+6). All operations may be used.

When a player places 5 of his tokens in a straight line orthogonally or diagonally, he scores points according to the colour of the squares they are located on : 1 point on a yellow square, 2 points on an orange square, 3 points on a red square.

The game ends when a player runs out of tokens. Each unplayed token is worth 1 point for each player. The player with the maximum score wins.

—user summary

name.value: Getting Started with Warhammer: Age of Sigmar

item.description:
This is a booklet with lots of introductory information around Warhammer: Age of Sigmar, including the core rules.
It also contains a Stormcast Eternal miniature to be used in the game.
—user summmary

A great introduction to Warhammer Age of Sigmar, this 96-page book contains a wealth of easy-to-follow information and guides welcoming the newcomer to this game system – and the rich and diverse stories it contains.

Inside This Book


 The Age of Sigmar: this is a history of the war for the mortal realms; a tale of gods and monster, brave heroes and diabolical villains;
 an introduction to the hobby of collecting Citadel miniatures – where to start, what to choose and where to go from there;
 a guide to the Grand Alliances – the four major factions in the war for the mortal realms;
 Great Rivals: in the mortal realms, a fierce battle rages. The Bloodbound and the Stormcast Eternals are the bitterest of rivals, one side fighting to restore order, the other revelling in absolute chaos. Included here is their story!
 2 full guides to painting: a guide to painting Citadel miniatures in general, with explanations of the types of Citadel paint, brushes and their uses; and detailed, specific guides to painting the miniatures from the Warhammer Age of Sigmar starter set;
 2 showcases: some amazing collections of Warhammer Age of Sigmar miniatures sit alongside a variety of stunningly painted individual models by the ‘Eavy Metal team;
 and of course the full rules for playing games or Warhammer Age of Sigmar. Grab some dice and play right away!"


—from the publisher

This is a four handed version of the abstract game Xiangqi, the latter also known as Chinese chess.

In the tradition game, the board is divided in half by a line called the river. In the four player version, one might call this a sea. Then each player uses a standard set of pieces set up on their half of a standard board. (Hence only two sets of standard pieces are needed. Ownership of pieces is marked by their orientation since they would read as right-side-up to the controlling player.) Where the river would normally be is extended into a large empty square. Pieces cross but do not go onto this space, the sea. Lines of the board extend across the sea no differently than across the river as far as players opposite each other are concerned. The lines of movement connect to players at either side's boards as if the board on which a player's pieces begin were rotated toward the player on either side. Play is clockwise and otherwise the standard rules of xiangqi apply in all instances.

If at the start of a player's turn, the player's "king" (to use Western terminology for simplicity) is checkmated-- whether by a single player's pieces or pieces of multiple players in combination-- that player is immediately eliminated from the game. Only the "king" is taken from the board but that player's turn is thereafter skipped. Remaining pieces may be taken but do not otherwise move. The last remaining player wins.

This is a game intended primarily for DIY play. Two sets of pieces are needed along with four half-boards. These can be printed from files on BGG or fashioned using multiple sets from the traditional game.

To play a 3 player variant, one of the 4 half-boards is simply not used. A 2 player variant would be the traditional game.

This is a web-published DIY 4 player version of shogi, a game also called Japanese chess.Each player sets up pieces as usual on the 4 back-rows of a shogi-ban (shogi board). In the center are 3 sets of a row of 9 spaces, one each to be shared between each possible pair of players. That shared row acts as a fifth row of a board shared by a given pair of players; only those two given players may nter or cross through the space. As usual orientation of a piece marks ownership. All standard rules of shogi apply.

For a 3 player version, one player's partial board is simply eliminated.

Gameplay is clockwise. To use Western terminology, a player whose "king" is checkmated at the start of their turn-- whether by a single player-s pieces or by a combination of players' pieces-- is eliminated. The "king" is removed from the board" and thereafter that player's turn is skipped. The last remaining player wins.

The goal of the game is always to be the first to get rid of his cards to score victory points and the theme of the game resumes the rivalry between Brutus and his father-in-law Caesar.

The first player is called Imperator and after the cards are dealt by the Slave player, he decides how many cards (1, 2 or 3) will be exchanged during the forum phase. Each player discards this number of cards and in the order of play, players take the cards of their choice. The slave discards the remaining cards.

The Imperator then plays a combination of cards (one or more cards of the same value, the cards being numbered from 1 to 13). The next player may pass or play the same number of cards but of higher value. This is played until no one wants (or can) beat the current combination. The player who placed this combination starts the next round.

Brutus is the weakest card in the game but it is the only card that can beat the strongest card that is ... Caesar. And we can play any card on Brutus, which can only be played on Caesar.

If the winning combination has a value between 9 and 13, it triggers an effect in favor of the player who asked it (discard cards, give cards to his opponents, earn points ...).

When a player no longer has a card in hand, he scores points of glory that vary according to the number of players and takes the Position card corresponding to his place (from the first Imperator to the last Slave).

When only one player remains with cards (who becomes the new slave), the round is over. After several rounds (to be defined at the beginning of the game), the player with the most points is the winner.

Not the same game as Brutus: The Board Game

Community card poker refers to any game of poker that uses community cards (also called "shared cards" or "window cards"), which are cards dealt face up in the center of the table and shared by all players. In these games, each player is dealt privately an incomplete hand ("hole cards"), which are then combined with the community cards to make a complete hand. The set of community cards is called the "board", and may be dealt in a simple line or arranged in a special pattern. Rules of each game determine how they may be combined with each player's private hand. The most popular community card game today is Texas hold 'em, originating sometime in the 1920s.

Also known as "flop poker", community card poker is a variation of stud poker. Players are dealt an incomplete hand of face-down cards, and then a number of face-up community cards are dealt to the center of the table, each of which can be used by one or more of the players to make a 5-card hand. Texas hold 'em and Omaha are two well-known variants of the community card family.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Draw poker is any poker variant in which each player is dealt a complete hand before the first betting round, and then develops the hand for later rounds by replacing, or "drawing", cards.

A complete hand is dealt to each player, face-down, and after betting, players are allowed to attempt to change their hand (with the object of improving it) by discarding unwanted cards and being dealt new ones. Five-card draw is the most famous variation in this family.

Five-card draw (also known as a Cantrell draw) is a poker variant that is considered the simplest variant of poker, and is the basis for video poker. As a result, it is often the first variant learned by new players.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Stud poker is any of a number of poker variants in which each player receives a mix of face-down and face-up cards dealt in multiple betting rounds. Stud games are also typically non-positional games, meaning that the player who bets first on each round may change from round to round (it is usually the player whose face-up cards make the best hand for the game being played). The cards dealt face down to each individual player are called hole cards, which gave rise to the common English expression ace in the hole for any hidden advantage.

Cards are dealt in a prearranged combination of face-down and face-up rounds, or streets, with a round of betting following each. This is the next-oldest family; as poker progressed from three to five-card hands, they were often dealt one card at a time, either face-down or face-up, with a betting round between each. The most popular stud variant today, seven-card stud, deals two extra cards to each player (three face-down, four face-up) from which they must make the best possible 5-card hand.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

In Soupe de nombres ("Soup of Numbers"), you must be the first to get an Objective Number.
To achieve this, combine the cards in play by applying different mathematical operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication and division), but use as little as possible!
The first players who wins 5 rounds is the winner.
—description from the publisher (translated)

À chaque manche, les joueurs s’efforcent d’être les premiers à obtenir un Nombre Objectif en combinant les cartes qui composent le Plateau de Jeu à l’aide de différentes opérations mathématiques (addition, soustraction, multiplication et division) et en utilisant le moins de cartes possible. Le premier joueur qui remporte 5 manches (sans se tromper) gagne la partie.
—description from the publisher (French)

Answer the questions correctly and with a little strategy and luck. Every turn, answer correctly 3 questions on 4 on a specific theme to collect enough money to seize the Champion’s chair. Be careful not to lose everything and challenge the “interim champ” with the Kif-Kif Duals. The player with the Champion’s chair at the end of the game (30 minutes) goes on to play the GRAND JEU DU 21. If the champion answer all the last 21 questions in 150 seconds, he/she is the GRAND CHAMPION.
Only available in french.
Box contains:
396 question cards
40 GRAND JEU DU 21 cards
55 cylinder cards
1 cylinder card container
CHAMPION’S CHAIR card
1 plastic base
1 small box
Game rules
(Description from the publisher)

Mezza means "half" in Italian – and in this game the ½ card is key. It is the lowest card in the game, but it can suddenly become the highest. The game is a quirky and fun variation of the popular 'shithead'. It has unique cards with a colourful design and the game has new exciting rules.

Played in groups from 2 to 5, the players try to get rid of their cards first to win. Each player is dealt three cards face down and three cards face up on top of them. Another three cards become the player's hand. The players take turns clockwise and play al least one card equal to or higher than the last card on the discard pile. They may play multiple cards of the same rank at once. If a player cannot play a card, he must pick up the discard pile and add it to his hand.

In the first stage of the game players play with the cards in their hand and replenish their hand with cards from the stock pile (to three). Once the stock pile and a player's hand is empty, the player may begin playing his face up cards and thereafter his face down cards one by one. At this point the game starts to become very strategic.

The game contains wildcards that may be played on every card and there are cards that activate a special action such as 'skip a turn' or 'play a card lower' (instead of higher). The ½ card is the twist of the game. It can be combined with the cards 3½, 6½ and 9½ to form a new rank (4, 7 or 10) and activate a corresponding action.

To play an extra fast and exciting game there is a short version of the game for 2 or 3 player in which some cards can be removed.

Lethal spies. Explosions. Deception. A fun, fast-paced strategy card game for 2-4 players. Each turn players draw a card to add to their hand. Your goal is to use these cards to reduce your opponents HP down to 0. With 5 different types of card you can expect each game to be filled with all sorts of combinations.

A fun game with words

Want to know a fast way to learn to read? Play the reading game from The Brainy Band!

Knowing letters is not enough to read! By playing Match and Catch, the kids will learn to put letters into words in a fun and easy way: whoever reads the fastest, gets the most tokens. The game is designed in such a way that the process automatically induces children to read and do it faster and faster.

To start the game, just open the box, place the tokens on the table and try to collect the most of these two-sided cards. The kids like to play, studying the brightly-coloured pictures and winning tokens. The game is great to take on the road, for vacation or to visit friends — wherever you are, prepare for some fun!

The game helps to develop the skill of reading words. Match and Simple rules and interesting game mechanics draw everyone in from the very first round.

A small memory game consisting of just nine cards showing fours geckos each. The geckos on each card have different colors, and every color is on exactly six of the cards.
The cards are shown face up so the players can memorize the geckos, then they are turn face-down. 
A color is chosen randomly, and one player asks the other to either turn over four cards showing a gecko of that color, or two colors not showing a gecko of that color.
If the other player manages to do that, they get a point, otherwise not. Then it's the second players turn to randomly choose a color and ask the first player to show or not show geckos in that color.
The game ends after all points are distributed. The player with the most points wins.

name.value: L.O.L. Surprise: 7 Layers of Fun Game

item.description:
The #1 collectible is now a board game featuring plenty of Surprises including unique gameplay and exclusive accessories. Which of your favorite L.O.L. Babies will you play in this Game where babies run everything! Merbaby, Queen Bee, Rocker or Diva who will you be? Collect and trade tokens to find out! Collect all 7 layers of Surprise to win. Comes with 4 exclusive accessories.
—description from the publisher

In this game, players take turns moving their bottle playing piece around the game board in an attempt to collect tokens of the same color in order to complete their L.O.L. Surprise doll and win the game.

Spin the spinner to find out how many spaces you get to move your bottle around the board. If you land on Unbox Me, select any Surprise Ball and take one of the tokens from it, adding it to the matching layer on your scorekeeper.

If you land on Trade Me, you can trade one of your collected tokens with a token from another player.

If you land on a Surprise space, you can take a token from any player or open up a Surprise Ball and collect any token you want from it.

Other spaces include Mix Me, where you must mix up the location of all of the Surprise Balls; Take a Peek, where you can only peek at what's inside a Surprise Ball but not collect a token; and Spin Again.

name.value: Pete the Cat: Big Lunch Card Game

item.description:
Pete the Cat is the coolest cat ever! Based on the best-selling book series, our Pete the Cat games introduce kids to simple learning concepts wrapped up in fun games. Kids develop color recognition, counting and decision-making skills. Keep on movin' and groovin' with Pete the Cat.

In Big Lunch Card Game, kids collect different cards to create a giant groovy sandwich using different colored food cards to win.

Reinforces color recognition and collaborative play
Features characters and images from Pete's Big Lunch

—description from the publisher

Game play:
On a turn, a player will either take the top card from the discard pile (unless it is an action card) or draw the top card from the draw deck and then will discard a card. If the player discards an action card, then the instructions on that card are followed before the next player takes their turn.

The winner is the first player to build a sandwich by collecting two bread cards and one each of the colored food cards (red, green, yellow, and purple)

In the future, explorers around the world discover secret staircases within ancient pyramids. At the bottom of the hundred thousand dusty steps are three doors. Anyone who opens a door is never heard from again. Whispered rumors speak of lost treasure, primeval technology, and nightmarish creatures. Powerfully driven adventurers arrive to bravely knock on DEATH’S DOOR.

Each player in DEATH’S DOOR has their own unique ways of gaining points centered around themes like exploring, killing, or looting. You win by completing the objectives described on your Story card and preventing other players from completing theirs. You must combine strategy, tactics, and diplomacy as you place and open dungeons, discover dangers, and gather powerful treasure.

Players start in different parts of the dungeon, and place tiles with a hex grid to create the board. You choose whether to join forces or fight solo. Lairs, with more monsters and a lair boss, are challenging and require multiple party members working together. The Final Boss is very difficult to defeat. The game ends when the Final Boss dies (everyone wins), or when there is one player left alive (highest score wins).

A simple yet dynamic attribute system defines the ability of players and monsters to engage the world. They describe how everyone attacks, defends, and acts. Taken together, they represent the health of the character. As you get bonuses to these attributes, you become more powerful. As you take damage, you become weaker. If all three attributes drop to one, the character is dead.

With only a dozen pages of rules and about two hours of play time, DEATH'S DOOR is designed to deliver RPG depth and lasting replayability that can be still learned and completed in one sitting.

—description from the designer

Talos: the Arena is an accessible deck-building game that is quickly mastered by everybody, but offers the veteran player great depth of tactics and many paths to victory. In preparation of the final battle in Talos’ arena you will spar with your enemies in search of winning combinations and the greatest heroes to truly represent your individual style and strategy. 
We created the game with the goal of enhancing the experience for everybody while eliminating bad elements common in other games. Thus, the basic mechanisms of the game include the following elements:

• To win you need to constantly interfere in your opponent’s turns, while risking and gaining small and large advantages. You actively play at all times during the game.

• There is no sequence of phases, just a never ending battle of all versus all. Players do not have to wait until the enemy has assembled an unbreakable combination to counteract it. You attack and intercept at will, even if your opponent charges forward.

• The game is designed to make as little restrictions as possible and to maximize the potential of the player’s creativity, cooperation, and clever deceit to affect the outcome.

• There is very little path dependency. There is no sure victor of the game practically until the very last move to ensure that you always have a chance to win and affect the game.

• There is only little preparation for the game. Just shuffle and go.

—description from the designer.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Join the Shopkins on a World Vacation! As you travel the globe, collect souvenirs from Vacation Spots in Europe, Asia, Australia, and the Americas. You can use Airport Spaces to quickly fly to new destinations, but watch out for Lost Luggage and Flight Delays that can slow you down.

Try to get the one very special Golden Ticket in the game that will allow you to collect souvenirs even faster! The first player to return home with four souvenirs wins the game!

La Planche is an abstract press your luck game for 1 to 4 players.
The board is divided in six zones, numbered from 1 to 6.
Each turn, a player roll a six-sided die and put one of his 6 tokens on the corresponding zone of the board, then he choses to continue rolling or to give the die to the player on his left. If the rolled die shows a number corresponding to a zone that already contains a token, the player who rolled the die takes all the tokens that are on the board, except those on zone 1 (tokens in zone 1 are blocked).
The first player who get rid of all his tokens wins the game.

On these game each player choose sides controlling the characters of the Justice league or the villains.
On every turn the players can do one of 5 different actions: move, attack, use a special card (usually a special attack), recover a life point or recovery a special card (both last two options only if you are in special positions in the board).
To move you must roll a die the show how much spaces you can move. To perform an attack you also roll one of two dice (one for bigger attacks and one for smaller attacks) if your character is in range (each character has different ranges where he can perform attacks). After an attack, the defender can roll a defense die. If the attack and defense die show the same color, nothing happens. If both show different, the defender loose a life of the attack die (if the defender doesn’t have those life color he loose a red point or two life points.
The team who survives wins the game.

Five years have passed, and it is the time once again for the Party Congress to assemble. Directives for the continued growth of our great Motherland must be established. Behind the scenes however, there is a power struggle brewing. There are party members who force through new directives solely to advance their own careers. The only certainty is that when the congress ends there will be a new General Secretary and many who stood his or her way will be purged.

In Join the Party, you take on the role of a power-hungry party member. Each turn, you will try to pass a directive with the help of another player. Beware though, there are other bureaucrats who may disagree with your ambitions. That is fine, as such disagreeable party members never survive long. Be careful to not be too disagreeable yourself, or it is you who may end up being purged. The player who has passed the most directives, and in doing so gained the most Victory Points, will be named the new General Secretary of the Party.

—description from the designer

You are feeding the hungry fish a fist full of worms (hand of worm cards). The goal of the base game is to be the first to feed all your worms to the fish (empty your hand). The fish mechanism gets programmed to know where all the players. The fish will make jokes, chuckle at players, ask for food, and make other comments while the game is in progress. When the game finishes, the fish will automatically announce the winner.

To start, every player gets a hand of cards that evenly distribute the 12 worm cards. The Fish mechanism gets setup by placing it on the base and pushing it's fin. The fish will spin and ask "Are you ready to play" at one of 4 player positions. If there is a player at the position, hit the fish fin to confirm. If not, wait a few seconds and the fish will skip to the next possible player position. Then the fish spins and randomly stops to face a player. It makes an automated comment like "I'm hungry" and waits for the player it's facing to add a worm card to it's mouth. Players need to be quick or the fish will skip the player. Once you put a worm in the fishes mouth, the fish will make a crunch noise, spin and then randomly stop on a player position, spit the worm card out and chuckle. It may spit the card out to the player who put the worm in it's mouth in the first place. This process will repeat and eventually one player will have no cards left in their hand and win the game. The Fish will announce the winner.

There is also an advance game play variant: To start the game, separate the cards into stacks by color. Each player chooses the stack of cards that match the color of their player number on the game base. Turn Fish Food ON, and all players press the fish’s fin.

Feed the fish when he spins to you, but instead of trying to get rid of your card, try to collect three cards of another player’s color! When you have collected three cards in another color, press the fish’s fin once - you’re the winner!

From the publishers website: Fish Food is the FINtastic game with the smart fish that knows how to play! If he lands on you, feed him one of your cards. Watch out on the next spin – he may spit the card back to you! Get rid of all of your cards to win. The fish knows who wins and will call out the winner at the end of the game.

Vertellis - which means "tell us more" in Dutch - is designed to create a moment in which families and friends become much closer by asking in-depth questions. Questions that make you reflect, cherish, and share the important and beautiful moments of life.

Vertellis is played through a total of four rounds. Cards are stacked in four piles as labeled on the back of each card, Round 1, Round 2, Round 3, and Round 4. Cards in Round 1 consist of questions answered individually about the past year. Cards in Round 3 consist of questions answered individually about the upcoming year.

Only in Rounds 2 and 4 can you receive points. These Rounds consist of three questions each that are answered by everyone. Each participant can earn a maximum of six points throughout the game. It is possible for more than one player to tie for the win, but we believe that during a successful night everyone's a winner!

A shadow rises over ancient Japan. Each night, storied terrors emerge from a dark gate to ravage the countryside. As all hope seems lost, a group of heroes stand together to fight back the Oni and their endless hordes.

Onimaru (Japanese for “demon circle”) is a fully cooperative game where you and your allies take up arms to defend a village against otherworldly invaders. You will win the game if you are able to destroy the three villainous Oni. However, if you fail to do so within the predetermined number of days (rounds), the Gate will remain open forever, and all of Japan will succumb to the shadow!

Each round begins with a preparation phase, where new enemies will appear from the Gate, and the Heroes may develop their skills. After that, each player will roll a set of dice and work together as a team to decide how to allocate, reroll, and sequence those dice. These dice can be used to attack your enemies directly, or combined in specific sets to execute powerful techniques. Finally, the Oni will roll its own dice to damage the Heroes, summon forth new Hordelings, and command those Hordelings in play to attack their targets.

Out of the box, you can choose to play the Heroes as recommended...or, through use of GameTrayz technology, you can customize and store your own unique Heroes! Each Hero can be built with any 2 of the 16 included Techniques (and their accompanying cards), any 3 of the included 24 Skills, and any of the 8 included Talents. Out of the box, over 1.9 million different combinations are possible!

The enemies also feature similar modularity. In each game, you will choose one of the three Oni to face of each Circle (difficulty tier). Each Oni is not only its own board, but also adds its own unique Attack cards and Hordeling cards to their respective deck. When an Oni is defeated, those Attack and Hordeling cards remain in those decks, as it passes its abilities and dark allies along to empower the next Oni!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: It’s a silly sequencing memory game! Kids learn animal sounds as they repeat them in order of the cards: Cow says Moo, Chicken says Bawk. Remembering who said what last and repeating the sequence of sounds is just half the fun! Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) add to the auditory fun as kids are asked to repeat certain sounds, make silly faces, or clap! Make the wrong noise or action and break the sequence (horse says, "Meow"?!), and the other players can grab the soft pig "squeal" on you! Builds brain power and auditory memory. Farm Alarm Game Silly sequencing memory game Encourages memory skills, communication, sequencing, auditory development Repeat the animal sounds in order Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) mean repeat, make funny faces, or clap Make a wrong noise and other players can "squeal" on you! Pig oinks when squeezed! Includes: 42 cards, soft rubber pig, barn storage box 2 or more players

Each of the 60 multi-level challenge cards will show you a combination of cubes that needs to be recreated. That's the easy bit. The hard bit is working out how to position the faces of the cubes correctly. Rows and columns of cubes must show either every face with the same expression, with each being a different colour, or every face having a different expression, but all the same colour. The rules have to apply from the front, back, sides and from above.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Spy, swap, and peek your way to the lowest score in this addictive card game of deception and fun. â€‹An addictive game of deception and fun. â€‹Your objective is to have the lowest score when any player goes over 100 points. How? Figure out which cards you have and accumulate fewer points than anyone else by replacing your high cards for low ones, swapping high cards for your opponents' low cards, and trading matching cards for a single card. Call "Keister" when you think you have the lowest score and hope to catch your opponents with a keister-full of high cards!

Creeps of Keister Island describes itself as a "cabo-golf" game and is mechanically identical to Cabo, reskinned with monster artwork.

Quiz game about the history of Denmark based on Sigurd Barretts books about the history of Denmark.

The players are famous characters from the Danish history, i.e. H.C Andersen or Margrethe the first. The players have to collect six treasures related to their character. The treasures are randomly spread over the board picturing Denmark.

To collect the treasures the players have answer multiple choise questions about the Danish history. There are three difficulties of questions.

Trailhead is a board game about surviving the extremes of the great outdoors. A dice game with a strategic twist, Trailhead is easy to learn and perfect for both the kitchen table or the campsite.

Lost in the wilderness and running low on water, your goal is to be the first player to reach the trailhead. Collect Trail Markers to move forward, but watch out—you lose water at the end of every turn!

As you venture through the wilderness, you can collect Survival Cards that give you a boost, hinder other players, or alter the trail itself.

PlingPong is a dexterity game. The game comes with four (4) interlocking trays to create a single game board, which holds a black cup in the middle and four (4) sets of six (6) colored cups on each tray. Each player get a color (or two (2) colors if playing with two (2) players).

Play is played on any table you can bounce a ping pong ball on. With the board setup diagonally, players shoot over their color, to hit the other player’s cups. In each round players shoot twice, then score the round; empty cups stay on the board, cups with an Odd number of balls come off and cups with an Even number of balls stay on.

The goal is to bounce your shots into the opponent’s cups, while avoiding the black cup in the middle.

If the black cup has an odd numbers of balls, each player who placed a ball in the cup lose one of their cups, and the other players gain a cup. Even if you have no cups left, you are still in the game, because you will get one back when someone makes a black cup shot.

The last player with cups on the board wins.

name.value: Rough Riders!: America's Little Wars of Empire

item.description:
Rough Riders! is a war game which depicts the battles of San Juan Heights and El Caney, in Cuba, and actions in the Philippines, between the eager, but nearly clueless, Army of the United States, and the highly experienced and far better equipped Armies of Spain, as well as the resultant insurgency of the Moro’s that came with acquisition of the Philippines.

Each Player represents a Commander who controls a number of Battalions, and it is his task to defeat the enemy through maneuver and firepower. Even though an Army may have many Battalions, and far outnumber their enemy, if the soldiers are new to war, discipline, and command, those advantages can quickly evaporate. To achieve victory with such an army, a Commander, by his personal example and with the help of his junior officers, must struggle to keep his confused and isolated men fighting and moving on their objective, or see them fail and die to no purpose.

Completely original, card driven, and exceptionally fast and "clean," no other set of rules on this subject has caught the essential problems of command and control as experienced by all forces engaged.

A special rules section for battles in Mindanao against the Moros are included which allow not only for hidden movement, but random generation of terrain as U.S. Forces advance across country mastered by inhabitants whose fanaticism became legendary.

The 74 page, 8.5" x 11" rules book comes with full color covers, 8 pages of color maps and flags to help identify units in play, as well as the complete Action Deck of cards paper printed in b&w, ready to cut out and use, as well as useful Game Markers which eliminate the need for written records.

Scaled at 1:10 and intended for 15mm or 25/28mm figures.

The game of quick thinking and fast talking!
It should be easy to name 3 animals found in a zoo - but can you do it under the pressure of 5 seconds twisting down and with the other players staring, waiting for you to get flustered? Time is not on your side, so just say what comes to mind and risk ridiculous answers slipping out as time twirls down on the spiral timer.
There are opportunities to 'duck' the questions or inflict 'pain' on your opponents by use of the SWITCH or PASS ON cards.
Contents:
90 Question cards (180 questions)
6 PASS ON cards
6 SWITCH cards
1 Spiral timer
1 Set of rules

The button pushing game of "limited" nuclear conflict for megalomaniacs, optimists and the ecologically retarded from 8-108.
—description from the box

Nukery is a political commentary game from the Cold War era that abstractly depicts the rush to assemble enough nuclear weapons to annihilate all other players. Four fictional "blocs" represent the players' home countries. Players move around regions within their country, collecting "nuke/no nuke" cards as they go. When they are satisfied with their arsenal they may attack, trading the nuke cards to draw Strike cards that may obliterate enemy territories or the attacking player's own territories.

Strange and terrible things have begun happening in Hawkins, Indiana… better huddle down and break out a nice board game with your pals!

 Monopoly game with a Stranger Things theme
 Features 80s-inspired tokens and tokens “ripped from the Upside Down”
 Walkie-Talkie and Blinking Lights cards as Community Chest and Chance cards

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Lay your Life! is a tile laying game for big and small conniseurs of the art of living. In a group or with a partner, here you spin yarns of a life.

Aim of the game is to lay down all your cards, by telling a good story. You'll create the convoluted biographies. After birth, your first steps, primary school you devide to live in the wild together with your friends to make plans to save the earth. It's about juggling with words and inventing stories.

It's the house-game of the Spielkartenfabrik Stralsund, invented here, developt, made and you also can buy it here in our workshop. So if you love telling stories, and want to think outside the box, you'll find with this hand-made deck of cards a completely new board game.

(Translated from the companie's website)

In When Cutie Met Patootie, we meet Cutie, the residents of Kodiak Harbor, and the ten alien visitors who have just arrived on nearby Alaskan shores. Cutie has been in the care of her grandmother while her archeologist parents are on a dangerous expedition. However, after their being gone for six months, Cutie and the residents of Kodiak Harbor fear the worst. Join Cutie as she travels into the forest with Amelia, one of the visitors, to discover the truth of her parents' whereabouts.

At the beginning of the game, players take a secret Citizen card and three path cards, then they randomly assemble the Alaskan shore visitor cards in a row of ten and place the corresponding Visitor pieces on their card.

Players then take turns playing a path card each turn. Path cards can be used in multiple ways: build the growing map, help visitors collect sprite gems, or spend those sprite gems to advance visitors along the built map. When building the map, players can connect only to the existing path to create a pyramid shape, ever tightening the forest path!

The end of the game is triggered when one visitor reaches the top. To determine a winner, players reveal their secret roles, each detailing specific sprite gems for which they earn points. Players tally points based on the location of visitors holding their designated sprite gems. The person with the most sprite gem points wins!

When Cutie Met Patootie is the first game of The Entanglement Series by The Daniel Zayas Company. This game ships with a mini-expansion titled The Man Who Moves the Water, which allows for solo play.

Do you dream about being a little K3 danser, joining Marthe, Klaasje and Hanne on stage? It's a lot harder then it seems! You have to learn a lot of dance moves! Do you want to try out? Try to get on the stage first and show of your moves, show that you know all the routings. Learn the dancemoves on the cards on the rotating stage and try to do them in sequence without faults but look out, the further you get the more moves you need to learn.And just when you think you mastered the routing someone might switch up the moves. Welcome to the K3 dance studio.

A roll and move, take that, memory dance game

Fourth Quarter Football miniatures game, recreating the thrill of gridiron football.

Coaches select plays from a play deck they have designed, in an attempt to outwit their opponents. The plays selected are played out on the highly detailed game field, with fantastically detailed miniatures. Players are rewarded for sticking to the planned plays, but it's the fourth quarter, and things get tough, and crucially, players make mistakes.

The game uses a unique two phase movement mechanism to recreate the feel of a football game, but plays in under one and a half hours.
Any actions are decided by dice rolls, but the chances of success depend on the skills and the placement of the players involved.

—description from the publisher
